title: Why Do Rioters Respond To Unimportant Stuff But Not Things Everyone Wants To Know?
body:
"Says hi to a rioter" - Rioter responds
"What type of jedi are you" - Rioter responds
"How old is Jhin, Fourty?" - Rioter responds
"Why does my shop not work?" - Rioter responds
"[Insert any question about the game like runes being ... or tanks being ..., etc]" - No response

But dont worry, Rioters say they see all but just dont post. Thats why Ardent Censor wasnt nerf for 6 months, even tho we complained about it on the boards everyday for 6 months. EleGiggle

replies.body:
Because unless they're 100% certain on the answer and are approved to publicly share that information it will have consequences.

If they answer a question and they do something else the community will respond feeling lied to.

And of course the issue of getting harassed if people don't like the answer.

So there are a few reasons. Here's some of them.

* Not every Rioter works with every part of the company. The right Rioter might not see the post.
* The community often posts questions in a very black/white manner, suggesting there is a certain right or wrong answer, or that something is simply horribly designed. That's not conducive to having a meaningful discussion.
* Rioters have full-time jobs, and the boards aren't necessarily part of that job. Posting is a nice thing they do sometimes, not a requirement.
* Rioters are, ultimately, also people, and also members of the community. They're totally allowed to interact and goof around with the community if/when they want to do so.

Between your list and Destaice's one, these are all the reasons.

EDIT: Although to be fair, no one approves what we say. But if we aren't certain or answer wrong players feel lied to or hurt, which is consequence enough in my mind. :c

The best approach is likely to post a well-reasoned, detailed post of your concerns. Rioters *do* often read the boards, I believe, even if they don't always comment. Don't take the lack of a comment or a hard answer as evidence they're ignoring your point.

The community is ENORMOUS, and not everyone can get a personal response.

> I mean, isn't it pretty big that those two champs can disable most of Ashe's kit for 6's+ just by ulting? And also deny her basic AA damage when it's already among the lowest ones of marksmen.

It's big, yes, but both of those characters are designed specifically to prey on character like Ashe, so it's still reasonable. She also has a defense against Master Yi in the form of her ultimate. But it's also a price Ashe pays for her vision control and utility the rest of the time -- she's incredibly strong against some compositions, and weak against certain characters. This is true of most of the champions in League, many of whom have characters they can't really do much about.

Off the top of my head, Nasus has a similar problem against both, Rammus messes up any fast attacking champion with just his W, Morgana can hard-counter any telegraphed ultimate, Alistar eats burst for lunch, Yasuo counters all projectiles, Braum intercepts targeted abilities, Azir stops gapclosers, Bard can stop ANYTHING, Fizz can dodge anything, Kindred can stop executes dead, etc. There are a lot of frustrating counters in the game, but that's part of the price that's paid for a diverse champion pool.

I'll admit I personally would be fine if Ashe's slow and mark applied differently so that she'd still trigger it vs. at least Yi, but I also don't think that one glaring weakness is legitimately that large a balance issue for either Ashe or the game as a whole.

Out of curiosity, what IS an Experience Designer? The title seems a bit vague in terms of the work you do because it could relate to a lot of things, at least in my mind.

An Experience Designer is kinda a cross between a game designer and an artist. Our main job is clarity - usually visual clarity in the user interface (so we work on things like the client or minimap etc) but that could extend to things like in game VFX clarity or even writing error messages.

Projects I've personally worked on include things like Runes, Elemental Dragons or the League Friends app.

EDIT: It's not a job people know of often in the games industry right now but it's a pretty common career in the more general tech industry

Ignoring the obvious hyperhostility in that comment I think there is a point in there, the new runes did a lot of damage to player choice and customisation.

For example I main Sej jungle and she has two runepages, one of which is a super cheesy Fleet Footwork page which is only good due to the absurd pace of the game allowing for an early game hyperaggressive page to work and the other is her 6 rune locked Aftershock page where there's almost no reason to ever deviate away from the optimal page, Aftershock/Unflinching/Conditioning/Overgrowh/Triumph/L:Alacrity. The last change to the way Resolve worked completely solidified this page.

The complete lack of any customisation is far worse now than it ever has been before.

I think it's a fair critique to call out particular cases where we could be doing more (in your example Sej). There are certainly different levels of options per champion right now and while I don't think we can ever avoid that completely, we do want to add more to make sure players/champs hit a minimum bar for choice. 

We are hoping to add or rework more runes at a quicker pace than we ever have before and certainly to build the system up more from the base version we've released with. Though I don't know that I agree with the assertion that it's far worse than ever before I will enthusiastically agree with fleshing it out more. :)

You can disagree with it being worse/better all you like as long as you acknowledge the issue. To me I didn't feel like old runes lacked customisation options, sure there was an optimal setup but at least that setup varied from game to game and there were also options like HP/lv yellows VS armour yellows which almost always existed. The new system to me completely lacks that variation, especially prevalent in the Resolve tree.

To me the big problem in the specific case of tank junglers is that the resolve tree seems tailor made for lane. Out of the 6 rune choices which aren't just a stat choice only one is actually good on junglers and it requires you to have innate sustain to be worth running. 

The top row is just horrible, straight up it's abysmal. The choices here all do next to nothing for a jungler, you can technically flex this rune choice, it's just that you don't get anything no matter what you run. Your choices are useless tenacity, damage on a tower you're probably never going to hit or healing for allies that you're rarely around. You generally take the tenacity simply because it's the least bad but that's a horrible state for runes to be in. To me this entire tier (possibly the whole tree TBH) is just in dire need of an overhaul, it fails to provide any interesting options and Demolish is actively destructive to the game.

The third row is better than this admittedly, but it still has huge issues in the jungle, although I'd say it's generally OK for lane. The problem is that the only mastery which isn't innately worse in jungle is Revitalise which is a conditional mastery, it's great if you're Zac, but garbage if you're Amumu. So for any jungler without sustain that leaves a choice between two very subpar options, you either run Overgrowth or Second Wind, Second Wind doesn't work on junglers due to the lack of poke based early trades in the jungle so you kind of get railroaded into Overgrowth, which is still significantly worse for junglers than laners since for some reason there aren't bonuses against jungle camps despite the fact that there's simply less to kill in the jungle than in a lane. To me this is a more salvageable than the first and second tier, I just think Overgrowth needs to be a better option for tank junglers and a new rune that's also a decent option needs to be added.

The second tier is arse, Mirror Shield is the second worst rune in the game after only Celestial body, a rune that literally makes you weaker if you take it and Iron Skin honestly isn't that much better. Conditioning is the clear best, but even at that it's pretty dull. This tier needs to be torn down and done again because it simply doesn't work, there's just not an interesting choice here at all.

Finally I question trying to force every champ who wants any defence, which probably works out to be about half of League's roster into a singular defensive tree. There's so many options for offence, 3 whole trees worth but almost none for defence. The absolute best option would be a split in Resolve, creating one tree which offered some more aggressive defensive bonuses (things like Aftershock and Unflinching) more appealing to Bruisers, Juggernauts and offensive Vanguards and the other being more centred around general defence for Wardens and other classes who just want to spec into more pure defence and defensive utility.

I'm going to build on this here, though I know you're probably the wrong person to answer the question but at least I hope you can pass it on to the right people:

With the changes to Resolve, which were aimed at helping top lane, tank junglers lose 65 health and gain...10 AP. Or 6 AD. Is that really supposed to help us? Is that supposed to be beneficial? Tanking isn't really about the early game anyway, if we cared about early game we would play Warwick or Lee Sin or Kayn. When I play {{champion:20}} or{{champion:32}} or {{champion:54}} I'm looking to scale in to the mid and late game, that's why Cinderhulk is such a great item for that. So then why take away half of the health I am intending to build and give me back a bit of AP, AD or AS that will help me from levels 1-3 and then simply be an empty part of my kit? Why is this being attached to Resolve Primary as a whole and not simply Grasp of the Undying/Resolve Secondary?

>Why is this being attached to Resolve Primary as a whole and not simply Grasp of the Undying/Resolve Secondary?

If it was on Grasp then most tanks would be forced into running Grasp/Precision since AS is such a powerful early stat in the jungle.

Tanks already have plenty of AS in the jungle between the AS changes from the preseason and Machete. Even then, you would get the same stats from going Fleet of Foot as you would from going Grasp, so you aren't forced to take Grasp. 

Tanks were doing just fine before the change when Resolve gave them no AS.

If I may leave my two cents, I'd say that at present there are many runes that are superior choices to others, among them runes that are taken less for their unique scalings and more for the free stats they provide (e.g. Transcendence being take more for the free 10% CDR than for the adaptive power per extra CDR, or Celerity and its free MS). As a personal opinion, Gathering Focus by contrast only grants its power above 70% health which can more easily be nullified in a world where burst damage can hit for more. Have there been alternate incarnations considered, like making it a periodic thing similar to Thresh's Flay passive?

If I'm understanding this right, you kinda take the input from either work already finished or from teams that are completing work, and then look at it from the player's point of view and say "what can i do to make this better feeling for the player"?

Kinda - we actually usually join the team at the beginning of a project, with that exact question in mind from the start. 

We also make prototypes and what's called 'wireframes' to prove out layouts & behavior ideas before they're coded (and to test what works with players), but we also do see projects through til the end.

You might see me commenting on a lot of bugs or wonky behavior with runes UI still - I consider all that stuff part of the experience (whether intentional or not) so there is also always a bit of follow up work too. :)
stuff like red ghost poro for both team (color stuff) or more something like decision about who see stuff (for exemple, gp barrel health just hide to teammate at some point)?

Both. Game Design is also heavily involved in both kinds of those decisions - there's quite a bit of overlap for anything in game. :)

EDIT: Also to be fair, many Experience Designers work outside of the game space at Riot so this wouldn't necessarily be applicable everyone. Most Experience Designers do primarily client, web or app work (I worked on the League Friends app before coming to the Runes team) so this answer is a little more personal to me specifically as a part of the Gameplay Systems team.
So your basically a manager?

Some of us are (not me), but the meat of an Experience Designer's job is as a team contributor - we make a lot of planning materials like 'wireframes', prototypes, documents on how things should work and what to do when they don't, etc. 

Also worth noting the more common title is a 'User Experience Designer' or 'UX Designer'. :)
